author: sky.cactus
content: More generally, there is no known way for humans to build such a protocol.

author: timbeiko
content: More more generally, EIP-1559 is already extremely complex, the biggest pushback seems to be that it's very hard to model such a wide-ranging change, and we're already likely going to make it more complex by adding the "escalator tip" so I'd strongly push back against anything that's not needed to ship a good V1.

author: timbeiko
content: I think that the fact that the tip fails under certain circumstances is probably good enough to use the escalator tip instead, but beyond that, it seems like we get rapidly increasing complexity for rapidly diminishing returns. Also, I think it's probably good to aim to get this live on mainnet before a lot of the other 1.x changes (i.e. witnesses, binary trie) also have to go into an upgrade.

author: sky.cactus
content: The UX on signing multiple transactions is *terrible*.

author: sky.cactus
content: Especially if you are using something like a hardware wallet.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, due to propagation time you end up missing out some opportunity, and you have to increment in 12% increments (which is a pretty big jump each step).

author: timbeiko
content: To be clear, I was arguing _for_ the escalator, but _against_ trying to do anything fancy with the burnt part of the fee for now.

author: .vbuterin
content: The "redistribute half the burnt fee to all miners" thing is tough, because on the one hand it's a complexity increase, on the other hand it's a security mitigation

author: sky.cactus
content: If we want to increase security we can just increase the block reward.

author: timbeiko
content: <@!273808422753796097> is there a longer form write-up on that anywhere? If so, I'll link it to the next call agenda.

author: sky.cactus
content: That would be *way* less complex (just a single constant change) and it would give us more confidence on exactly how much security was being provided (not a function of congestion/usage).

author: sky.cactus
content: I still haven't seen, and would like to see, an actual attack described that is mechanistically sound.  Has someone presented one yet?  Each time I have heard people suggest this, they hand wave over important details.
